verses.text: O LORD, you have searched me and known me.
verses.comment: The psalmist affirms God’s complete knowledge of him. The use of 'searched' points to a deep, intentional understanding.

verses.text: You know when I sit down and when I rise up; you discern my thoughts from afar.
verses.comment: God’s knowledge is not confined to actions but extends to internal contemplation.

verses.text: You search out my path and my lying down and are acquainted with all my ways.
verses.comment: Every movement and moment of the psalmist’s life is under God’s gaze. This echoes a theme of God’s providential care.

verses.text: Even before a word is on my tongue, behold, O LORD, you know it altogether.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience encompasses not only thoughts but also intentions and speech.

verses.text: You hem me in, behind and before, and lay your hand upon me.
verses.comment: The imagery suggests protection, enclosure, and guidance—a sign of God’s intimate and caring authority over the believer.

verses.text: Such knowledge is too wonderful for me; it is high; I cannot attain it.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is awe-inspiring and beyond human comprehension (compare to Paul’s doxology in Romans).

verses.text: Where shall I go from your Spirit? Or where shall I flee from your presence?
verses.comment: 'Spirit' here prefigures the Holy Spirit’s role—God’s presence is inescapable as in later theology.

verses.text: If I ascend to heaven, you are there! If I make my bed in Sheol, you are there.
verses.comment: God’s presence transcends all realms—earthly and spiritual. Equally a comfort and a warning.

verses.text: If I take the wings of the dawn and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea,
verses.comment: Even at the farthest reaches of creation, the psalmist cannot escape God’s presence.

verses.text: Even there your hand shall lead me, and your right hand shall hold me.
verses.comment: ‘Hand’ and ‘right hand’ are images of God’s guidance and power (cf. Psalm 23).

verses.text: If I say, "Surely the darkness will cover me, and the light about me be night,"
verses.comment: The darkness cannot hide the psalmist from God—a theme reflected in Jesus as the Light in the New Testament.

verses.text: even the darkness is not dark to you; the night is as bright as the day, for darkness is as light with you.
verses.comment: This verse has spiritual depth—God’s light dispels all darkness, a major theme pointing to Christ as 'the light of the world.'

verses.text: For you formed my inward parts; you knitted me together in my mother’s womb.
verses.comment: Acknowledges God as the personal Creator with a plan for every individual from the womb.

verses.text: I praise you, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Wonderful are your works; my soul knows it very well.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the dignity of the human person as God’s work—a profound point for Christian anthropology.

verses.text: My frame was not hidden from you, when I was being made in secret, intricately woven in the depths of the earth.
verses.comment: ‘Depths of the earth’ is a poetic way to speak of the hiddenness of the womb and God’s creative power even before birth.

verses.text: Your eyes saw my unformed substance; in your book were written, every one of them, the days that were formed for me, when as yet there was none of them.
verses.comment: God’s foreknowledge and providential plan evoke the Christian understanding of predestination, but with space for freedom and cooperation with grace.

verses.text: How precious are your thoughts to me, O God! How vast is their sum!
verses.comment: God’s thoughts here denote His providence and wisdom—immeasurable and attentive.

verses.text: If I would count them, they are more than the sand. I awake, and I am still with you.
verses.comment: The psalmist sleeps and wakes in God’s presence, hinting at trust in God even through death and resurrection metaphors.

verses.text: Oh that you would slay the wicked, O God! O men of blood, depart from me!
verses.comment: The psalmist’s zeal for God includes a prayer for separation from evil. Justice and righteousness are central.

verses.text: They speak against you with malicious intent; your enemies take your name in vain.
verses.comment: Blasphemy and opposition to God’s name is denounced—a theme recurring throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Do I not hate those who hate you, O LORD? And do I not loathe those who rise up against you?
verses.comment: This is holy zeal—not personal hatred but a call to align one’s heart with God’s righteousness.

verses.text: I hate them with complete hatred; I count them my enemies.
verses.comment: Strong language is characteristic of Hebrew poetry. In Christ, perfect love transforms this righteous hatred into love for enemies; see Matthew 5:44.

verses.text: Search me, O God, and know my heart; test me and know my thoughts!
verses.comment: Openness to God’s searching is the attitude of a humble and teachable disciple.

verses.text: And see if there is any wicked way in me, and lead me in the way everlasting.
verses.comment: The psalm ends with a prayer for continuous guidance and growth in holiness, expressing ongoing cooperation with God’s grace—preparing the heart for salvation in its fullest sense.
